org.chronos.chronodb.api

Interface TransactionSource

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    ChronoDB, ChronoDBInternal, TemporalKeyValueStore
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractChronoDB, AbstractTemporalKeyValueStore, ChunkDbTkvs, ChunkedChronoDB, InMemoryChronoDB, InMemoryTKVS, JdbcChronoDB, JdbcTkvs, MapDBChronoDB, MapDBTkvs, TemporalKeyValueStoreBase, TuplChronoDB, TuplTkvs

    public interface TransactionSource
    A TransactionSource is an object capable of producing a variety of ChronoDBTransactions.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      default ChronoDBTransaction tx()
      Produces and returns a new instance of ChronoDBTransaction on the master branch head version.
      default ChronoDBTransaction tx(long timestamp)
      Produces and returns a new instance of ChronoDBTransaction on the master branch at the given timestamp.
      default ChronoDBTransaction tx(java.lang.String branchName)
      Produces and returns a new instance of ChronoDBTransaction on the head version of the given branch.
      default ChronoDBTransaction tx(java.lang.String branchName, long timestamp)
      Produces and returns a new instance of ChronoDBTransaction at the given timestamp on the given branch.
      ChronoDBTransactionBuilder txBuilder()
      Creates a new ChronoDBTransactionBuilder for fluent transaction configuration.

    • Method Detail

      • tx

        default ChronoDBTransaction tx()
        Produces and returns a new instance of ChronoDBTransaction on the master branch head version.

        Opening a read transaction is a cheap operation and can be executed deliberately. Also, there is no need to explicitly close or terminate a read transaction.

        Note that transactions are in general not thread-safe and must not be shared among threads.

        Returns:
        The transaction. Never null.

      • tx

        default ChronoDBTransaction tx(long timestamp)
                        throws InvalidTransactionTimestampException
        Produces and returns a new instance of ChronoDBTransaction on the master branch at the given timestamp.

        Please note that implementations may choose to refuse opening a transaction on certain timestamps, e.g. when the desired timestamp is in the future. In such cases, an InvalidTransactionTimestampException is thrown.

        Opening a transaction is a cheap operation and can be executed deliberately. Also, there is no need to explicitly close or terminate a transaction.

        Note that transactions are in general not thread-safe and must not be shared among threads.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to use. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        The transaction. Never null.
        Throws:
        InvalidTransactionTimestampException - Thrown if the transaction could not be opened due to an invalid timestamp.

      • tx

        default ChronoDBTransaction tx(java.lang.String branchName)
                        throws InvalidTransactionBranchException
        Produces and returns a new instance of ChronoDBTransaction on the head version of the given branch.

        Opening a transaction is a cheap operation and can be executed deliberately. Also, there is no need to explicitly close or terminate a read transaction.

        Note that transactions are in general not thread-safe and must not be shared among threads.

        Parameters:
        branchName - The name of the branch to start a transaction on. Must not be null. Must be the name of an existing branch.
        Returns:
        The transaction. Never null.
        Throws:
        InvalidTransactionBranchException - Thrown if the transaction could not be opened due to an invalid branch name.

      • tx

        default ChronoDBTransaction tx(java.lang.String branchName,
                               long timestamp)
                        throws InvalidTransactionBranchException,
                               InvalidTransactionTimestampException
        Produces and returns a new instance of ChronoDBTransaction at the given timestamp on the given branch.

        Please note that implementations may choose to refuse opening a transaction on certain timestamps, e.g. when the desired timestamp is in the future. In such cases, an InvalidTransactionTimestampException is thrown.

        Opening a transaction is a cheap operation and can be executed deliberately. Also, there is no need to explicitly close or terminate a transaction.

        Note that transactions are in general not thread-safe and must not be shared among threads.

        Parameters:
        branchName - The name of the branch to start a transaction on. Must not be null. Must be the name of an existing branch.
        timestamp - The timestamp to use. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        The transaction. Never null.
        Throws:
        InvalidTransactionBranchException - Thrown if the transaction could not be opened due to an invalid branch.
        InvalidTransactionTimestampException - Thrown if the transaction could not be opened due to an invalid timestamp.

      • txBuilder

        ChronoDBTransactionBuilder txBuilder()
        Creates a new ChronoDBTransactionBuilder for fluent transaction configuration.

        When you have called all relevant configuration methods, use ChronoDBTransactionBuilder.build() to receive the configured ChronoDBTransaction.

        Returns:
        The transaction builder.
